2.name: COMP 1010
2.title: Introductory Computer Science 1
2.desc-full: (Lab Required) An introduction to computer programming using a procedural high level language. May not be held with COMP 1011 or COMP 1012 or COMP 1013. Prerequisite: any grade 12 or 40S Mathematics, or equivalent.
2.desc: An introduction to computer programming using a procedural high level language. May not be held with COMP 1011 or COMP 1012 or COMP 1013.
2.prerequisite-full: any grade 12 or 40S Mathematics, or equivalent.

3.name: COMP 1012
3.title: Computer Programming for Scientists and Engineers
3.desc-full: (Lab Required) An introduction to computer programming suitable for solving problems in science and engineering. Students will implement algorithms for numerical processing, statistical analysis and matrix operations. Not to be held with COMP 1010, COMP 1011 or COMP 1013. Prerequisite: Mathematics 40S or equivalent. Co-requisite: MATH 1230 or MATH 1500 or MATH 1501 (or equivalent).
3.desc: An introduction to computer programming suitable for solving problems in science and engineering. Students will implement algorithms for numerical processing, statistical analysis and matrix operations. Not to be held with COMP 1010, COMP 1011 or COMP 1013.
3.prerequisite-full: Mathematics 40S or equivalent. Co-requisite: MATH 1230 or MATH 1500 or MATH 1501 (or equivalent).

5.name: COMP 1020
5.title: Introductory Computer Science 2
5.desc-full: (Lab Required) More features of a procedural language, elements of programming. May not be held with COMP 1021. Prerequisite: COMP 1010 or COMP 1011 (C); or COMP 1012 or COMP 1013 (C); or High School Computer Science 40S (75%) and any grade 12 or 40S Mathematics, or equivalent.
5.desc: More features of a procedural language, elements of programming. May not be held with COMP 1021.
5.prerequisite-full: COMP 1010 or COMP 1011 (C); or COMP 1012 or COMP 1013 (C); or High School Computer Science 40S (75%) and any grade 12 or 40S Mathematics, or equivalent.

6.name: COMP 1500
6.title: Computing: Ideas and Innovation
6.desc-full: An introduction to the topics of Computer Science and problem solving. Students will learn concepts in computer programming. May not be used to fulfill computer science requirements in a Computer Science Honours, Major, General or Minor program. Not available to students who have previously obtained credit in, or are concurrently registered in any of COMP 2080, COMP 2130, COMP 2140, COMP 2150, COMP 2160 or COMP 2280.
6.desc: An introduction to the topics of Computer Science and problem solving. Students will learn concepts in computer programming. May not be used to fulfill computer science requirements in a Computer Science Honours, Major, General or Minor program. Not available to students who have previously obtained credit in, or are concurrently registered in any of COMP 2080, COMP 2130, COMP 2140, COMP 2150, COMP 2160 or COMP 2280.

7.name: COMP 1600
7.title: Navigating Your Digital World
7.desc-full: Topics related to digital society such as security, encryption and data storage, issues of social and ethical importance, and current events. May not be used to fulfill computer science requirements in a Computer Science Honours, Major, General or Minor program. Not available to students who have previously obtained credit in, or are concurrently registered in any of COMP 2080, COMP 2130, COMP 2140, COMP 2150, COMP 2160 or COMP 2280. May not be held with the former COMP 1270.
7.desc: Topics related to digital society such as security, encryption and data storage, issues of social and ethical importance, and current events. May not be used to fulfill computer science requirements in a Computer Science Honours, Major, General or Minor program. Not available to students who have previously obtained credit in, or are concurrently registered in any of COMP 2080, COMP 2130, COMP 2140, COMP 2150, COMP 2160 or COMP 2280. May not be held with the former COMP 1270.

8.name: COMP 2080
8.title: Analysis of Algorithms
8.desc-full: Methods of analyzing the time and space requirements of algorithms. Average case and worst case analysis. Models of computation. Prerequisites: MATH 1240 (C), MATH 1241 (C) or COMP 2130 (C); and one of COMP 2140, or the former COMP 2061 (C). STAT 1000 or STAT 1001 or STAT 1150 is strongly recommended.
8.desc: Methods of analyzing the time and space requirements of algorithms. Average case and worst case analysis. Models of computation.
8.prerequisite-full: MATH 1240 (C), MATH 1241 (C) or COMP 2130 (C); and one of COMP 2140, or the former COMP 2061 (C). STAT 1000 or STAT 1001 or STAT 1150 is strongly recommended.

9.name: COMP 2130
9.title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
9.desc-full: An introduction to the set theory, logic, integers, combinatorics and functions for today's computer scientists. Prerequisites: COMP 1020 or COMP 1021 (C), and a "C" in one of: MATH 1210, MATH 1211, MATH 1220, MATH 1300, MATH 1301, MATH 1310; and one of: MATH 1230, MATH 1500, MATH 1501, MATH 1510, MATH 1520, or MATH 1690.
9.desc: An introduction to the set theory, logic, integers, combinatorics and functions for today's computer scientists.
9.prerequisite-full: COMP 1020 or COMP 1021 (C), and a "C" in one of: MATH 1210, MATH 1211, MATH 1220, MATH 1300, MATH 1301, MATH 1310; and one of: MATH 1230, MATH 1500, MATH 1501, MATH 1510, MATH 1520, or MATH 1690.

10.name: COMP 2140
10.title: Data Structures and Algorithms
10.desc-full: (Lab Required) Introduction to the representation and manipulation of data structures. Topics will include lists, stacks, queues, trees, and graphs. May not be held with COMP 2061. Prerequisites: one of COMP 1020, COMP 1021 (C).
10.desc: Introduction to the representation and manipulation of data structures. Topics will include lists, stacks, queues, trees, and graphs. May not be held with COMP 2061.

11.name: COMP 2150
11.title: Object Orientation
11.desc-full: Design and development of object-oriented software. Topics will include inheritance, polymorphism, data abstraction and encapsulation. Examples will be drawn from several programming languages. Prerequisite: COMP 2160; and one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C).
11.desc: Design and development of object-oriented software. Topics will include inheritance, polymorphism, data abstraction and encapsulation. Examples will be drawn from several programming languages.
11.prerequisite-full: COMP 2160; and one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C).

12.name: COMP 2160
12.title: Programming Practices
12.desc-full: (Lab Required) Introduction to issues involved in real-world computing. Topics will include memory management, debugging, compilation, performance, and good programming practices. Prerequisite: COMP 1020 (C+) or COMP 1021 (C+).
12.desc: Introduction to issues involved in real-world computing. Topics will include memory management, debugging, compilation, performance, and good programming practices.

13.name: COMP 2190
13.title: Introduction to Scientific Computing
13.desc-full: An applied computational course introducing topics such as approximation by polynomials, solution of non-linear equations, linear systems, simulation and computational geometry. May not hold with COMP 2191. Prerequisites: One of COMP 1020 or COMP 1021, or COMP 1012 (C) or COMP 1013 (C); and one of MATH 1230, MATH 1500, MATH 1501 (C), MATH 1510 (C), MATH 1520 (C), or MATH 1690 (C). Prerequisite or concurrent registration: One of MATH 1220, MATH 1300, MATH 1301, or MATH 1310.
13.desc: An applied computational course introducing topics such as approximation by polynomials, solution of non-linear equations, linear systems, simulation and computational geometry. May not hold with COMP 2191.
13.prerequisite-full: One of COMP 1020 or COMP 1021, or COMP 1012 (C) or COMP 1013 (C); and one of MATH 1230, MATH 1500, MATH 1501 (C), MATH 1510 (C), MATH 1520 (C), or MATH 1690 (C). Prerequisite or concurrent registration: One of MATH 1220, MATH 1300, MATH 1301, or MATH 1310.

14.name: COMP 2280
14.title: Introduction to Computer Systems
14.desc-full: (Lab Required) Data representation and manipulation, machine-level representation of programs, assembly language programming, and basic computer architecture. Not available to students who have previously completed ECE 3610. Prerequisites: COMP 2140 (C), COMP 2160 (C), and one of MATH 1240 (C), MATH 1241 (C) or COMP 2130 (C).
14.desc: Data representation and manipulation, machine-level representation of programs, assembly language programming, and basic computer architecture. Not available to students who have previously completed ECE 3610.
14.prerequisite-full: COMP 2140 (C), COMP 2160 (C), and one of MATH 1240 (C), MATH 1241 (C) or COMP 2130 (C).

15.name: COMP 2980
15.title: Workterm 1
15.desc-full: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment. (Pass/Fail)
15.desc: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment. (Pass/Fail)

16.name: COMP 3010
16.title: Distributed Computing
16.desc-full: An introduction to the development of client server and peer-to-peer systems through web applications, distributed programming models, and distributed algorithms. Prerequisite: COMP 2150 (C) or ECE 3740 (C).
16.desc: An introduction to the development of client server and peer-to-peer systems through web applications, distributed programming models, and distributed algorithms.

17.name: COMP 3020
17.title: Human-Computer Interaction 1
17.desc-full: Human-computer interaction: human factors and usability, user-centered design, prototyping, usability evaluation. Prerequisite: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061 (C). A course in cognitive psychology, such as PSYC 2480, is recommended.
17.desc: Human-computer interaction: human factors and usability, user-centered design, prototyping, usability evaluation.
17.prerequisite-full: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061 (C). A course in cognitive psychology, such as PSYC 2480, is recommended.

18.name: COMP 3030
18.title: Automata Theory and Formal Languages
18.desc-full: An introduction to automata theory, grammars, formal languages and their applications. Topics: finite automata, regular expressions and their properties; context-free grammars, pushdown automata and properties of context-free languages; Turing machines and their properties. Prerequisite: COMP 2080 (C).
18.desc: An introduction to automata theory, grammars, formal languages and their applications. Topics: finite automata, regular expressions and their properties; context-free grammars, pushdown automata and properties of context-free languages; Turing machines and their properties.

19.name: COMP 3040
19.title: Technical Communication in Computer Science
19.desc-full: This course is designed to help students become more effective and confident writers in the context of the computing profession. Students will be introduced to a broad range of written and oral presentation styles used in the computing workplace. Prerequisite: Students must be enrolled in third year (or higher) of a majors or honours program in the Department of Computer Science.
19.desc: This course is designed to help students become more effective and confident writers in the context of the computing profession. Students will be introduced to a broad range of written and oral presentation styles used in the computing workplace.
19.prerequisite-full: Students must be enrolled in third year (or higher) of a majors or honours program in the Department of Computer Science.

20.name: COMP 3090
20.title: Digital Logic 2
20.desc-full: Design and implementation of digital circuits. Minimization and state reduction, asynchronous circuits, arithmetic circuits, implementation using modern hardware techniques. May not to be held with ECE 2220. Prerequisite: COMP 2280 (C).
20.desc: Design and implementation of digital circuits. Minimization and state reduction, asynchronous circuits, arithmetic circuits, implementation using modern hardware techniques. May not to be held with ECE 2220.

21.name: COMP 3170
21.title: Analysis of Algorithms and Data Structures
21.desc-full: Fundamental algorithms for sorting, searching, storage management, graphs, databases and computational geometry. Correctness and analysis of those algorithms using specific data structures. An introduction to lower bounds and intractability. Prerequisites: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C); and COMP 2080 (C).
21.desc: Fundamental algorithms for sorting, searching, storage management, graphs, databases and computational geometry. Correctness and analysis of those algorithms using specific data structures. An introduction to lower bounds and intractability.
21.prerequisite-full: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C); and COMP 2080 (C).

22.name: COMP 3190
22.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
22.desc-full: Principles of artificial intelligence: problem solving, knowledge representation and manipulation; the application of these principles to the solution of 'hard' problems. Prerequisite: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C).
22.desc: Principles of artificial intelligence: problem solving, knowledge representation and manipulation; the application of these principles to the solution of 'hard' problems.

23.name: COMP 3290
23.title: Introduction to Compiler Construction
23.desc-full: Introduction to the standard compiler phases: scanning, parsing, symbol-table management, code generation, and code optimization. The emphasis is on the simpler techniques for compiler construction such as recursive descent. Prerequisites: COMP 2140 (or COMP 2061)(C) and COMP 2280 (or ECE 3610)(C). COMP 2160 is recommended.
23.desc: Introduction to the standard compiler phases: scanning, parsing, symbol-table management, code generation, and code optimization. The emphasis is on the simpler techniques for compiler construction such as recursive descent.
23.prerequisite-full: COMP 2140 (or COMP 2061)(C) and COMP 2280 (or ECE 3610)(C). COMP 2160 is recommended.

24.name: COMP 3350
24.title: Software Engineering 1
24.desc-full: Introduction to software engineering. Software life cycle models, system and software requirements analysis, specifications, software design, testing and maintenance, software quality. Prerequisites: COMP 2150 (C) or ECE 3740 (C).
24.desc: Introduction to software engineering. Software life cycle models, system and software requirements analysis, specifications, software design, testing and maintenance, software quality.

25.name: COMP 3370
25.title: Computer Organization
25.desc-full: Principles of computer systems architecture, organization and design. Performance, instruction sets, processors, input/output, memory hierarchies. Prerequisite: COMP 2280 (C) or ECE 3610 (C).
25.desc: Principles of computer systems architecture, organization and design. Performance, instruction sets, processors, input/output, memory hierarchies.

26.name: COMP 3380
26.title: Databases Concepts and Usage
26.desc-full: An introduction to database systems including the relational, hierarchical, network and entity-relationship models with emphasis on the relational model and SQL. Prerequisite: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C).
26.desc: An introduction to database systems including the relational, hierarchical, network and entity-relationship models with emphasis on the relational model and SQL.

27.name: COMP 3430
27.title: Operating Systems
27.desc-full: (Lab Required) Operating systems, their design, implementation, and usage. Prerequisites: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C); and COMP 2280 (C) or ECE 3610 (C). COMP 2160 is recommended.
27.desc: Operating systems, their design, implementation, and usage.
27.prerequisite-full: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C); and COMP 2280 (C) or ECE 3610 (C). COMP 2160 is recommended.

28.name: COMP 3440
28.title: Programming Language Concepts
28.desc-full: An introduction to major concepts involved in the design of modern programming languages. The imperative, functional, and logical families and differences between them. Facilities for high level data and control structures, modular programming, data typing, and other topics will be covered. Prerequisite: one of COMP 2140 or COMP 2061(C).
28.desc: An introduction to major concepts involved in the design of modern programming languages. The imperative, functional, and logical families and differences between them. Facilities for high level data and control structures, modular programming, data typing, and other topics will be covered.

29.name: COMP 3490
29.title: Computer Graphics 1
29.desc-full: An introductory course in computer graphics including topics such as raster graphics, two and three dimensional transforms, and simple rendering. Prerequisite: COMP 2140 (C); and either COMP 2190 (C), or a C in both: MATH 1300 (or MATH 1220, MATH 1310, MATH 1301, MATH 1210 or MATH 1211) and MATH 1500 (or MATH 1230, MATH 1501, MATH 1510 or MATH 1520).
29.desc: An introductory course in computer graphics including topics such as raster graphics, two and three dimensional transforms, and simple rendering.
29.prerequisite-full: COMP 2140 (C); and either COMP 2190 (C), or a C in both: MATH 1300 (or MATH 1220, MATH 1310, MATH 1301, MATH 1210 or MATH 1211) and MATH 1500 (or MATH 1230, MATH 1501, MATH 1510 or MATH 1520).

30.name: COMP 3820
30.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Algorithms
30.desc-full: An introduction to problems in molecular biology and computational solutions. Focus on design and analysis of efficient algorithms. Prerequisites: COMP 2080. Suggested prerequisite: MBIO 1410. Suggested concurrent requirement: COMP 3170.
30.desc: An introduction to problems in molecular biology and computational solutions. Focus on design and analysis of efficient algorithms.
30.prerequisite-full: COMP 2080. Suggested prerequisite: MBIO 1410. Suggested concurrent requirement: COMP 3170.

31.name: COMP 3980
31.title: Workterm 2
31.desc-full: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment. (Pass/Fail). Prerequisite: COMP 2980 (P).
31.desc: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment. (Pass/Fail).

32.name: COMP 4020
32.title: Human-Computer Interaction 2
32.desc-full: Advanced issues in the field of human-computer interaction. Topics will be selected from current research and development issues in the field of HCI. Prerequisite: COMP 3020 (C). A course in cognitive psychology such as PSYC 2480 is recommended.
32.desc: Advanced issues in the field of human-computer interaction. Topics will be selected from current research and development issues in the field of HCI.
32.prerequisite-full: COMP 3020 (C). A course in cognitive psychology such as PSYC 2480 is recommended.

33.name: COMP 4050
33.title: Project Management
33.desc-full: Introduction to the issues involved in managing large, complex software projects. Prerequisite: COMP 3350 (C).
33.desc: Introduction to the issues involved in managing large, complex software projects.

34.name: COMP 4060
34.title: Topics in Computer Science
34.desc-full: This course will examine topics of interest at the fourth-year level. Specific topics will vary from year to year. Topics will be selected from current research in computer science. Prerequisite: Departmental permission.
34.desc: This course will examine topics of interest at the fourth-year level. Specific topics will vary from year to year. Topics will be selected from current research in computer science.

35.name: COMP 4140
35.title: Introduction to Cryptography and Cryptosystems
35.desc-full: Description and analysis of cryptographic methods used in the authentication and protection of data. Classical cryptosystems and cryptoanalysis, the Advanced Data Encryption Standard (ADES) and Public-key cryptosystems. Prerequisite: one of MATH 1240 (C), MATH 1241 (C) or COMP 2130 (C). Students must be registered in Computer Engineering or fourth year of a Major or Honours program in the Department of Computer Science.
35.desc: Description and analysis of cryptographic methods used in the authentication and protection of data. Classical cryptosystems and cryptoanalysis, the Advanced Data Encryption Standard (ADES) and Public-key cryptosystems.
35.prerequisite-full: one of MATH 1240 (C), MATH 1241 (C) or COMP 2130 (C). Students must be registered in Computer Engineering or fourth year of a Major or Honours program in the Department of Computer Science.

36.name: COMP 4180
36.title: Intelligent Mobile Robotics
36.desc-full: Topics include artificial intelligence, computer vision, human-robot interaction, and multi-robot systems. These abstract components are grounded in the problem of developing a team of intelligent mobile robots. All topics are covered with specific emphasis on applied problems, e.g. real-time performance. Not to be held with the former COMP 4060 –“Mobile Robotics”. Prerequisites: COMP 2160 and COMP 3190 (C).
36.desc: Topics include artificial intelligence, computer vision, human-robot interaction, and multi-robot systems. These abstract components are grounded in the problem of developing a team of intelligent mobile robots. All topics are covered with specific emphasis on applied problems, e.g. real-time performance. Not to be held with the former COMP 4060 –“Mobile Robotics”.

37.name: COMP 4190
37.title: Artificial Intelligence
37.desc-full: Reasoning with temporal knowledge; causal reasoning; plausible reasoning; nonmonotonic reasoning; abductive reasoning. Prerequisite: COMP 3190 (C).
37.desc: Reasoning with temporal knowledge; causal reasoning; plausible reasoning; nonmonotonic reasoning; abductive reasoning.

38.name: COMP 4200
38.title: Expert Systems
38.desc-full: Organization of expert systems; knowledge representation in expert systems; inference; knowledge engineering; tools for building expert systems; limitations of expert systems. Prerequisite: COMP 3190 (C).
38.desc: Organization of expert systems; knowledge representation in expert systems; inference; knowledge engineering; tools for building expert systems; limitations of expert systems.

39.name: COMP 4300
39.title: Computer Networks
39.desc-full: (Lab required) This course examines the principles of computer networks, including network architectures, algorithms, protocols, and performance. May not be held with the former COMP 3720 or the former COMP 4720 or ECE 3700. Prerequisite: COMP 2280 (C) and COMP 3010 (C).
39.desc: This course examines the principles of computer networks, including network architectures, algorithms, protocols, and performance. May not be held with the former COMP 3720 or the former COMP 4720 or ECE 3700.

40.name: COMP 4340
40.title: Graph Theory Algorithms 1
40.desc-full: Spanning trees, connectivity, planar graphs, directed graphs, networks, colouring problems and tours are studied and their applications to computer science will be highlighted. Prerequisite: COMP 3170 (C).
40.desc: Spanning trees, connectivity, planar graphs, directed graphs, networks, colouring problems and tours are studied and their applications to computer science will be highlighted.

41.name: COMP 4350
41.title: Software Engineering 2
41.desc-full: Advanced treatment of software development methods. Topics will be selected from requirements gathering, design methodologies, prototyping, software verification and validation. Prerequisite: COMP 3350 (C).
41.desc: Advanced treatment of software development methods. Topics will be selected from requirements gathering, design methodologies, prototyping, software verification and validation.

42.name: COMP 4360
42.title: Machine Learning
42.desc-full: Learning strategies; evaluation of learning; learning in symbolic systems; neural networks, genetic algorithms. May not be held with ECE 4450. Prerequisite: COMP 3190.
42.desc: Learning strategies; evaluation of learning; learning in symbolic systems; neural networks, genetic algorithms. May not be held with ECE 4450.

43.name: COMP 4380
43.title: Database Implementation
43.desc-full: Implementation of modern database systems including query modification/optimization, recovery, concurrency, integrity, and distribution. Prerequisite: COMP 3380 (C).
43.desc: Implementation of modern database systems including query modification/optimization, recovery, concurrency, integrity, and distribution.

44.name: COMP 4420
44.title: Advanced Design and Analysis of Algorithms
44.desc-full: Algorithm design with emphasis on formal techniques in analysis and proof of correctness. Computational geometry, pattern matching, scheduling, numeric algorithms, probabilistic algorithms, approximation algorithms and other topics. Prerequisites: COMP 3170 (C) and (STAT 1000 (C) or STAT 1001 (C) or STAT 1150 (C)).
44.desc: Algorithm design with emphasis on formal techniques in analysis and proof of correctness. Computational geometry, pattern matching, scheduling, numeric algorithms, probabilistic algorithms, approximation algorithms and other topics.
44.prerequisite-full: COMP 3170 (C) and (STAT 1000 (C) or STAT 1001 (C) or STAT 1150 (C)).

45.name: COMP 4430
45.title: Operating Systems 2
45.desc-full: Design and implementation of modern operating systems. Detailed analysis of an open source modern operating system and hands-on experience with its kernel and major components. Prerequisites: COMP 2160 (C) and COMP 3430 (C).
45.desc: Design and implementation of modern operating systems. Detailed analysis of an open source modern operating system and hands-on experience with its kernel and major components.

46.name: COMP 4490
46.title: Computer Graphics 2
46.desc-full: Methods in computer graphics including topics such as representation of curves and surfaces, viewing in three dimensions, and colour models. Prerequisite: COMP 3490 (C).
46.desc: Methods in computer graphics including topics such as representation of curves and surfaces, viewing in three dimensions, and colour models.

47.name: COMP 4510
47.title: Introduction to Parallel Computation
47.desc-full: An overview of the architectures of current parallel processors and the techniques used to program them. Not to be held with ECE 4530. Prerequisites: COMP 3370 (C) and COMP 3430 (C).
47.desc: An overview of the architectures of current parallel processors and the techniques used to program them. Not to be held with ECE 4530.

48.name: COMP 4520
48.title: Undergraduate Honours Project
48.desc-full: A research based project on a specific area of computer science. Students must find a faculty supervisor and write a proposal in their penultimate term. If acceptable, the defined research is to be carried out in the student's final term. Permission to take the course is given on an individual basis. Available to 4th Year students only. Prerequisite: departmental permission.
48.desc: A research based project on a specific area of computer science. Students must find a faculty supervisor and write a proposal in their penultimate term. If acceptable, the defined research is to be carried out in the student's final term. Permission to take the course is given on an individual basis. Available to 4th Year students only.

49.name: COMP 4550
49.title: Real-Time Systems
49.desc-full: An introduction to the theory and practice of real-time systems. Topics include the design of real-time systems, scheduling, event based processing, and real-time control. This course may not be held for credit if a student has previously completed both of ECE 4240 and ECE 3760. Prerequisites: COMP 3430 (C) and COMP 3370 (C).
49.desc: An introduction to the theory and practice of real-time systems. Topics include the design of real-time systems, scheduling, event based processing, and real-time control. This course may not be held for credit if a student has previously completed both of ECE 4240 and ECE 3760.

50.name: COMP 4560
50.title: Industrial Project
50.desc-full: Students will work in teams on an industrial project. Projects are supplied by the Department. Prerequisites: COMP 3350 (C) and departmental permission.
50.desc: Students will work in teams on an industrial project. Projects are supplied by the Department.

51.name: COMP 4580
51.title: Computer Security
51.desc-full: (Lab Required) Computer security and information management. This course will examine state-of-the-art knowledge about the issues relevant to data and computer security. Prerequisite: COMP 3430 (C) and COMP 3010 (C).
51.desc: Computer security and information management. This course will examine state-of-the-art knowledge about the issues relevant to data and computer security.

52.name: COMP 4620
52.title: Professional Practice in Computer Science
52.desc-full: Background and rationale to view Computer Science in a professional context. Examination of professional ethics, intellectual property, and privacy considerations important to Computer Scientists. May not be held with the former COMP 3620. Prerequisite: COMP 3350 (C).
52.desc: Background and rationale to view Computer Science in a professional context. Examination of professional ethics, intellectual property, and privacy considerations important to Computer Scientists. May not be held with the former COMP 3620.

53.name: COMP 4690
53.title: Computer Systems and Architecture
53.desc-full: Investigation of today's modern computer architecture and system design concepts, including requirements, specifications, and implementation. Instruction sets, instruction-level parallelism, speculative execution, multi-threaded architectures, memory hierarchy, multiprocessors, storage design and implementation, and interconnection networks. Prerequisite: COMP 3370 (C).
53.desc: Investigation of today's modern computer architecture and system design concepts, including requirements, specifications, and implementation. Instruction sets, instruction-level parallelism, speculative execution, multi-threaded architectures, memory hierarchy, multiprocessors, storage design and implementation, and interconnection networks.

54.name: COMP 4710
54.title: Introduction to Data Mining
54.desc-full: Introduction to data mining concepts and their applications. Prerequisite: COMP 3380 or consent of department.
54.desc: Introduction to data mining concepts and their applications.

55.name: COMP 4740
55.title: Advanced Databases
55.desc-full: Parallel, distributed, object-oriented, object-relational, and XML databases; other emerging database technologies. Prerequisite: COMP 3380 (C).
55.desc: Parallel, distributed, object-oriented, object-relational, and XML databases; other emerging database technologies.

56.name: COMP 4980
56.title: Workterm 3
56.desc-full: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment. (Pass/Fail). Prerequisite: COMP 3980 (P).
56.desc: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment. (Pass/Fail).

57.name: COMP 4990
57.title: Workterm 4
57.desc-full: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment (Pass/Fail). Prerequisite: COMP 4980 (P).
57.desc: Work assignment in business, industry, or government for students registered in the Computer Science Cooperative Option. Requires submission of a written report covering the work completed during the four-month professional assignment (Pass/Fail).
